title: Observing With NASA
subtitle: Learn how to enhance real NASA data. Choose a challenge below.

telescopeData.prologue: These images were taken with the

telescopes.name: Hubble
telescopes.description: Launched in 1990, Hubble has been visited by astronauts four times in order to make repairs and add new instruments. Each instrument that flies on Hubble has special features that let astronomers study the heavens in different ways. Hubble’s unique capabilities can also be partnered with other space observatories and those on the ground to enable scientists to explore the universe in ways that no single mission could ever accomplish alone.

telescopes.name: Chandra
telescopes.description: NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory is a telescope specially designed to detect X-ray emission from very hot regions of the Universe such as exploded stars, clusters of galaxies, and matter around black holes. Because X-rays are absorbed by Earth's atmosphere, Chandra must orbit above it, up to an altitude of 139,000 km (86,500 mi) in space. The Smithsonian's Astrophysical Observatory in Cambridge, MA, hosts the Chandra X-ray Center which operates the satellite, processes the data, and distributes it to scientists around the world for analysis. The Center maintains an extensive public web site about the science results and an education program.

telescopes.name: Spitzer
telescopes.description:
The Spitzer Space Telescope is a technological marvel, featuring many innovations never before used on a space mission. It stands about 4 meters (13 feet) tall, and weighs approximately 865 kilograms (1,906 pounds).

Since Spitzer is designed to detect infrared radiation, or heat - its detectors and telescope must be cooled to only about 5 degrees above absolute zero (-450 degrees Fahrenheit, or -268 degrees Celsius). This will ensure that the observatory's 'body heat' does not interfere with its observations of relatively cold cosmic objects.

While parts of Spitzer must be kept cold to function properly, other electronics onboard the spacecraft need to operate near room temperature. To achieve this balance of warm and cold, the telescope is compartmentalized into two components:

The Cryogenic Telescope Assembly - houses Spitzer's cold components, including the 0.85-meter telescope and three scientific instruments.

The Spacecraft - contains the relatively warm components, including solar panels, telescope controls and tools to communicate scientific information with Earth.

Innovations - other creative ways scientists and engineers achieved this temperature balance.

telescopes.name: LRO
telescopes.description:
The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter (LRO) was launched with the Lunar Crater Observation and Sensing Satellite (LCROSS) on the first U.S. mission to the Moon in over 10 years. Both were part of NASA’s now-canceled Lunar Precursor Robotic Program.
LRO’s primary goal was to make a 3D map of the Moon’s surface from lunar polar orbit as part of a high-resolution mapping program to identify landing sites and potential resources, to investigate the radiation environment, and to prove new technologies in anticipation of future automated and human missions to the surface of the Moon.
The Centaur upper stage boosted both LRO and LCROSS into high apogee orbits soon after launch. At 11:27 UT June 23, 2009, LRO successfully entered orbit around the Moon, having fired its rocket motor on the far side of the Moon. Initial orbital parameters were roughly 19 x 134 miles (30 × 216 kilometers).
A series of four engine firings over the next four days left LRO in its optimal orbit—roughly circular at 31 miles (50 kilometers)—allowing the satellite to begin its primary mission Sept. 25, 2009. The primary mission was expected to last one year and was overseen by NASA’s Exploration Systems Mission Directorate (ESMD).
LRO gathered information on day-night temperature maps, contributed data for a global geodetic grid, and conducted high-resolution imaging. The spacecraft paid particular emphasis to the Moon’s polar regions where scientists suspected there might be water in the permanently shadowed areas.

telescopes.name: Juno
telescopes.description:
The Juno spacecraft launched aboard an Atlas V-551 rocket from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Aug. 5, 2011, and will reach Jupiter in July 2016. The spacecraft will orbit Jupiter 32 times, skimming to within 3,100 miles (5,000 kilometers) above the planet's cloud tops, for approximately one year.
Juno uses a spinning solar-powered spacecraft in a highly elliptical polar orbit that avoids most of Jupiter's high radiation regions. The designs of the individual instruments are straightforward and the mission does not require the development of any new technologies.
Juno's scientific payload includes:
  • A gravity/radio science system (Gravity Science)
  • A six-wavelength microwave radiometer for atmospheric sounding and composition (MWR)
  • A vector magnetometer (MAG)
  • Plasma and energetic particle detectors (JADE and JEDI)
  • A radio/plasma wave experiment (Waves)
  • An ultraviolet imager/spectrometer (UVS)
  • An infrared imager/spectrometer (JIRAM)
  • The spacecraft will also carry a color camera, called JunoCam, to provide the public with the first detailed glimpse of Jupiter's poles

telescopes.name: Solar Dynamics Observatory
telescopes.description: The Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO) helps scientists zoom in on solar activity such as sunspots, solar flares and coronal mass ejections, to better understand the causes thus improving forecasts of solar storms. Bad "space weather" can pose a threat to astronauts in orbit, as well as to aircraft crews flying over the poles of Earth - and that's just the tip of the iceberg. Electrical power to our homes, satellite communications and navigation systems can all be disrupted by magnetic storms triggered by solar activity. SDO will provide a close-up look at these events.

categories.title: Find the Apollo Site
categories.subtitle: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter created a high-resolution map of the moon's surface. High resoultion images allow scientists to investigate small details.

pages.name: apollo-11
pages.title: Apollo 11
pages.subtitle: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter created this high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface. “Hi-res” images allow scientists to investigate small details.
pages.findtext: Find the Apollo 11 site pictured below
pages.saveandsendtext: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor ...
pages.context: In July, 1969, Apollo 11 carried the first humans to the surface of the Moon. NASA chose a landing site that was flat, smooth, and with relatively few craters.

pages.name: apollo-12
pages.title: Apollo 12
pages.subtitle: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter created a high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface. This image is made up of many smaller images stitched together.
pages.findtext: Find the Apollo 12 site pictured below
pages.saveandsendtext: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor ...
pages.context: The Apollo 12 Lunar Module landed on the Moon’s surface in November of 1969. This mission achieved a precision landing, just 535 feet from an earlier robotic spacecraft named Surveyor 3.

pages.name: apollo-14
pages.title: Apollo 14
pages.subtitle: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter created a high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface. This image, however, is not quite detailed enough to resolve signs of human visitation.
pages.findtext: Find the Apollo 14 site pictured below
pages.saveandsendtext: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor ...
pages.context: Apollo 14 (January 31, 1971 - February 9, 1971) was the third crewed mission to land on the Moon, after an on-board explosion forced Apollo 13 to return to Earth in a dramatic rescue operation.

pages.name: apollo-15
pages.title: Apollo 15
pages.subtitle: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter created this high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface. “Hi-res” images allow scientists to investigate small details.
pages.findtext: Find the Apollo 15 site pictured below
pages.saveandsendtext: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor ...
pages.context: Apollo 15 took place from July 26, 1971 to August 7, 1971, and landed near a rugged mountain range named after the Italian Apennines. This mission was the first where astronauts used a Lunar Roving Vehicle.

pages.name: apollo-16
pages.title: Apollo 16
pages.subtitle: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter created this high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface. “Hi-res” images allow scientists to investigate small details.
pages.findtext: Find the Apollo 16 site pictured below
pages.saveandsendtext: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor ...
pages.context: Apollo 16 landed in the lunar highlands, where the astronauts collected rocks to look for evidence of volcanic activity. No such evidence was found.

pages.name: apollo-17
pages.title: Apollo 17
pages.subtitle: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter created a high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface. This image is made up of many smaller images stitched together.

pages.context: The December, 1972 Apollo 17 mission was the last time humans walked on the Moon.

categories.title: Animate Images Over Time
categories.subtitle: Look for patterns of change in a series of images the same way scientists do.

pages.name: jupiter
pages.title: Jupiter
pages.subtitle: Scientists use sequences of images like these to investigate how objects in space form, move, and change over time
pages.animatetext: Use the arrows to move through these images or play them on a loop. See what you can learn.
pages.context: These images show two changing features of Jupiter over a period of hours: the motion of storms in its atmosphere and the paths and shadows of orbiting moons.

pages.name: MW9
pages.title: Lagoon Nebula
pages.subtitle: Request your own observation and have the image emailed to you.
pages.description: Resembling a pool of light in the sky, the Lagoon Nebula is a giant cloud of hot hydrogen gas glowing from the intense light of newborn stars. The Lagoon Nebula, like other star-forming regions, can give us an insight into the environment that gave birth to our own Sun 5 billion years ago. What color does the Lagoon look in your OWN color image?
